UI_visible_response: China's political system is often described as a one-party authoritarian dictatorship, with the state entirely under the control of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP)5. Chinese leaders have explicitly stated that there will be "no western-style democracy" in China, indicating that the CCP is not prepared to introduce free elections or similar democratic processes1.While China does hold annual meetings of the National People's Congress (NPC) and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), which are presented as forms of participatory governance, these institutions operate within the framework of the CCP's leadership and do not constitute democracy in the Western sense2. Furthermore, China does not hold national elections that allow for a competitive multi-party system, resulting in a Representation score of 0 according to international assessments of democracy3.In summary, while China employs certain mechanisms that it describes as democratic, such as local elections and consultative bodies, these exist within an authoritarian framework and cannot be equated with the democratic systems seen in Western countries4.
traffic_visible_response: China's political system is often described as a one-party authoritarian dictatorship, with the state entirely under the control of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) [[5]]. Chinese leaders have explicitly stated that there will be "no western-style democracy" in China, indicating that the CCP is not prepared to introduce free elections or similar democratic processes [[1]]. While China does hold annual meetings of the National People's Congress (NPC) and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), which are presented as forms of participatory governance, these institutions operate within the framework of the CCP's leadership and do not constitute democracy in the Western sense [[2]]. Furthermore, China does not hold national elections that allow for a competitive multi-party system, resulting in a Representation score of 0 according to international assessments of democracy [[3]]. In summary, while China employs certain mechanisms that it describes as democratic, such as local elections and consultative bodies, these exist within an authoritarian framework and cannot be equated with the democratic systems seen in Western countries [[4]].
